snippet: The sense of uncertainty and delay within the system, the judge wrote, “violates the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.”
abstract: United States District Court Judge Cormac J Carney rules California's death penalty system is so arbitrary and plagued with delay that it is unconstitutional; decision is expected to inspire similar arguments in death penalty appeals in states around country, but legal sweep will depend on California's likely appeal; state has not had an execution since 2006, and 40 percent of its 748 death row inmates have been there more than 19 years.

byline.original: By ERIK ECKHOLM and JOHN SCHWARTZ
byline.contributor: Erik Eckholm reported from La Quinta, and John Schwartz from New York.

lead_paragraph: The sense of uncertainty and delay within the system, the judge wrote, “violates the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.”

headline.main: California Death Penalty System Is Unconstitutional, Federal Judge Rules
headline.print_headline: California Death Penalty System Unconstitutional, Federal Judge Rules
